summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) and Special Technologies and Applications Office (STAG) to scan and process telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The records are from an address book belonging to Jeffrey Epstein that Rodriguez attempted to sell, which is believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice investigation. He was Epstein's former house manager and butler who came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional underage victims, which he attempted to sell rather than turn over to authorities.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Referenced as the employer of Alfredo Rodriguez and the subject of a child prostitution case. The address book in question belonged to him and contained contact information for his associates and potential underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Miami Division opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: The FBI's Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Timeframe for telephone records collection
events.description: Telephone records generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (June 22, 2010) are prioritized for processing in the investigation.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (DocLab - Telephone Application Audit Processing Team, Federal Bureau of Investigation, 170 Marcel Drive)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, came into possession of an address book belonging to Epstein containing names and telephone numbers believed to be additional, previously unknown underage victims.

Rodriguez attempted to sell this address book rather than turn it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas issued during pending civil litigation, leading to an FBI obstruction of justice case against him opened in October 2009.

The FBI is processing telephone records from this address book, believed to belong to Epstein and his associates or potential underage victims, for incorporation into their Telephone Application (TA) investigative database.

The document is a formal request for the FBI's Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and automate these telephone records, and for the Special Technologies and Applications Office to format the data for investigative use.
The telephone number 323-666-9942 is specified as a target for data loading into the Telephone Application.
